body_content.explanation: a person from the county (= area with its own local government) of Lancashire or the city of Lancaster in northwestern England:
examples: He is himself a Lancastrian, from Morecambe.
Robert is a quiet but plain-spoken Lancastrian.

body_content.explanation: someone who was on the side of the House of Lancaster during the English Wars of the Roses (1455–1487) fought between the Houses of Lancaster and York:
examples: Edward IV defeated the Lancastrians at Tewkesbury in 1471.

body_content.explanation: from or relating to the county (= area with its own local government) of Lancashire or the city of Lancaster in northwestern England:
examples: He spoke with a broad Lancastrian accent.
Pies are part of my Lancastrian heritage.
This part of Cumbria was Lancastrian until 30 years ago.

body_content.explanation: belonging or relating to the side of the House of Lancaster during the English Wars of the Roses (1455–1487) fought between the Houses of Lancaster and York:
examples: The church was destroyed by the Lancastrian army in their sack of the town in 1461.
Richard confiscated the Lancastrian estates to divide among his allies.
